email_chain.subject: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Initial Offer
email_chain.body:
Hello Vincente,

Based on last year's grain harvest data, we anticipate a lower wheat supply this year.

I can arrange a wheat shipment from Odessa to Barcelona in early August. Our standard demurrage clause for this route is USD 300,000.

Looking forward to your reply soon.

Best regards,
Tom Miller

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Initial Offer
email_chain.body:
Tom,

Good to hear from you.

We are anticipating potentially higher demurrage fees than usual due to port congestion. We also expect a 5% increase in the insurance premium. 

Assuming these costs can be managed, we're still targeting an early August completion for this transaction.

Waiting for your reply.

Regards,
Eddie Garcia

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Initial Offer
email_chain.body:
Vincente,

Just a reminder about the grain shipment offer. Are you anticipating high demand for wheat in early August?

Looking forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Tom Miller

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Initial Offer
email_chain.body:
Tom,

Apologies for the delayed reply. We've had some concerns raised by our banks regarding market fluctuations and the associated financial guarantees.

We're willing to proceed with the contract provided we can ensure a mutually beneficial outcome upon completion of the grain transaction.

Regards,
Vincente Rodriguez

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Initial Offer
email_chain.body:
Vincente,

Thanks for your prompt reply.

We have a contingency plan in place to address potential concerns raised by the banks, should any issues arise.

Looking forward to working with you.

Best regards,
Tom Miller

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Contract Signing
email_chain.body:
Vincente,

Is the contract still on track to be signed?

Tom Miller

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Contract Signing
email_chain.body:
Yes, we will sign the contract. We anticipate completing the transaction within one week.

Eddie Garcia

email_chain.subject: Re: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Contract Signing
email_chain.body:
Excellent news!

I'm looking forward to the transaction!

Tom Miller

email_chain.subject: Wheat Shipment from Odessa to Barcelona - Contract Confirmation
email_chain.body:
Dear Tom,

Please sign the contract and send the confirmation email to us.

If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to reach out.

Regards,
Vincente Rodriguez

email_chain.subject: Vessel Readiness Inquiry - 3,300MT Lubricants Genoa to Haifa
email_chain.body:
Dear Sir/Madam,

Please advise on vessel readiness for a shipment of 3,300MT of lubricants from Genoa to Haifa this Friday, if at all possible.

Could you please acknowledge receipt of this email?

Kind regards,
Giulia

email_chain.subject: Re: Vessel Readiness Inquiry - 3,300MT Lubricants Genoa to Haifa
email_chain.body:
Dear Giulia,

To assess vessel suitability, could you please provide the following information:

*   Type of ship required (e.g., container, bulk)?
*   Deadweight Tonnage (DWT) requirement?
*   Estimated Time of Arrival (ETA) desired?

If a container ship is preferred, please provide Vessel Instructions in PDF format as an attachment to your reply.

If you haven't secured space with a shipping line yet, please send details once arranged so I can confirm our rate competitiveness.

Does your company currently conduct VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) business with major oil companies? If so, please advise typical rates and fixing practices, preferably in US Dollars.

Upon shipment completion, please send a copy of the Bill of Lading (B/L) or Original Bill of Lading (OBL). The original B/L or OBL should be sent to our agent in Haifa for delivery to the buyer.

Thank you for your inquiry. I look forward to your reply.

Best regards,
Fred Gomez

email_chain.subject: Re: Vessel Readiness Inquiry - 3,300MT Lubricants Genoa to Haifa
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Gomez,

Thank you for your email. We are still awaiting confirmation from the client regarding their chosen shipping line. We will inform you as soon as we receive their confirmation.

We are able to provide competitive rates for VLCC fixing or spot charters. Could you please provide information regarding the types of vessels you typically fix? This includes DWT range, vessel age, agency details, and similar relevant information.

Best regards,
Giulia

email_chain.subject: Re: Confirmation of our rates and service for shipment of 3300MT lubricants from Genoa to Haifa.
email_chain.body:
Dear Giulia,

I am awaiting confirmation from the ship owner regarding your inquiry. Please let me know if you have any updates on your end.

I have alternative space available for you next Friday. The owners require confirmation this week. If you would like to secure this space in advance, I can arrange a fix with another charterer. Please let me know if you would like to proceed with a pre-confirmation booking before hearing back from the original ship owner.

Thank you. Best regards,
Fred.

email_chain.subject: Confirmation of our rates and service for shipment of 3300MT lubricants from Genoa to Haifa.
email_chain.body:
Dear Giulia,

In response to your email of 11/28/08, we would like to advise that we have sufficient, fixed VLCC cargo space available for 3,300 MT of lubricants. The loading port is Genoa, and the discharge port is Haifa. We can arrange delivery from the loading port by truck, rail, or barge as needed.

The rate for carriage by sea is EUR 14,000 per MT. Our estimated additional charges are EUR 20,000 and USD 400. (See attached Exhibit A for a breakdown).

Our commission rate is USD 1,000.

The Incoterm for this shipment is CIF, as detailed in the attached general terms and conditions (Exhibit B).

The bill of lading is our standard form.

Best Regards,
[email protected]

email_chain.subject: Freight Quote Request: Wood Panels - Bordeaux to Bilbao
email_chain.body:
Sven,

We're looking to ship 5,500 MT of wood panels from Bordeaux to Bilbao. Please send your rate ideas along with a preliminary quote and any specific questions you might have.

Sincerely,
Jeremy

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Request: Wood Panels - Bordeaux to Bilbao
email_chain.body:
Hi Jeremy,

Thanks for your email regarding the transport of wood panels from Bordeaux to Bilbao. To provide an accurate quote, I need a bit more information.

Could you confirm the dimensions and weight of the panels? If they are approximately 1.6 cubic meters (a typical wood pallet size) with a panel thickness of about 2.5cm, that would equate to approximately 1,000kg/m3 density, totaling 1,600kg per panel.

Do you have precise measurements or a specification sheet available?

Regards,
Susan

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Request: Wood Panels - Bordeaux to Bilbao
email_chain.body:
Hi Susan,

Thanks for the quick response. Yes, your assumptions are correct. All panels are approximately 1.6 cubic meters and 2.5cm thick, so your calculation of 1,600kg per panel is accurate.

Could you please provide the following information:

*   What is the maximum cubic meter capacity of your truck for this route (Bordeaux to Bilbao)?
*   How many trips will be required to transport the entire shipment (5,500 MT)?
*   What would be the total cost for transport, including all associated fees?

Thanks!
Jeremy

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Request: Wood Panels - Bordeaux to Bilbao
email_chain.body:
Hi Jeremy,

Thanks for confirming the details. 

Our trucks can transport approximately 24 cubic meters per trip from Bordeaux to Bilbao. Given the total volume, we estimate the total cost for transporting the 5,500 MT of wood panels to be 10,000 euros. This price includes customs costs and standard administrative fees within the EU and at the destination.

Will you require any special handling equipment or have any other specific requirements for loading or unloading?

Regards,
Susan

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Request: Wood Panels - Bordeaux to Bilbao
email_chain.body:
Hello Susan,

This sounds promising! I have a few more questions regarding the transport details. 

Would it be possible to discuss these details in person, perhaps over the phone or via video call? I'm available now if that works for you.

Thanks,
Jeremy

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Request: Wood Panels - Bordeaux to Bilbao
email_chain.body:
Hello Jeremy,

Yes, we can certainly discuss the details further. If it's more convenient, I can also meet you at the cargo port in Bordeaux. The coordinates are 44.8370° N, 0.5980° W.

Is that acceptable for you?

Regards,
Susan

email_chain.subject: Freight Rate Inquiry - 6600 MT Household Chemicals from Antwerp
email_chain.body:
Dear Betsy,

We're expecting 6,600 MT of household chemicals to be ready for shipment from Antwerp this Friday. Could you please confirm your best and final freight rate for this cargo?

Thank you,

David Miller

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Rate Inquiry - 6600 MT Household Chemicals from Antwerp
email_chain.body:
Hi David,

I can confirm that our rate remains at US$2.00 per ton FOB Antwerp. Please also note there's an additional charge of US$10 per package if the cargo is comprised of packages with varying dimensions.

Should you require any further details, please don't hesitate to ask.

Best wishes,

Betsy Ross

email_chain.subject: FW: Freight Rate Inquiry - 6600 MT Household Chemicals from Antwerp
email_chain.body:
Here we go again! This is the third request for a quote today, and David seems to be asking for a specific final rate even though I sent him the standard pricing already. Why do I have to explain this every time?

What are some reasons for replying to an email twice?

Paragraph 2 (this one) gives specific reasons in the writer’s first email. Your email serves to remind me that David is not as familiar with the company’s rates as I am.

Explain how this form of explanation might serve to establish greater rapport

email_chain.subject: Re: FW: Freight Rate Inquiry - 6600 MT Household Chemicals from Antwerp
email_chain.body:
Hi Dave,

Why don't you just offer the rate per ton and let David accept it or suggest alternatives?

Do you remember in our training course, we learned that the purpose of most email communications is not just to reply with 'yes' or 'no', but to help others make a decision? 

David's just a little reluctant, but he will accept it and agree to it if you can help him to make a decision by making your rate specific enough.

Best wishes,

Betsy

email_chain.subject: Re: Re: FW: Freight Rate Inquiry - 6600 MT Household Chemicals from Antwerp
email_chain.body: Dave, I wrote you an email in the last section. Please tell me how you replied.

email_chain.subject: Petroleum Coke - Cape Town
email_chain.body:
Hello my old friend,

A little birdie tells me you have an urgent need to get 3,000 MT of petroleum coke into Cape Town. I heard you're short on space on the F/A ABLYN, currently in Latakia? Are you going to wait for her next stop after a quick turnaround in Sudan, or are you looking for an immediate solution?

Yours,
Sid

email_chain.subject: Re: Petroleum Coke - Cape Town
email_chain.body:
Hi again,

Let me give you the full story. I might have something for you, an offer you can’t refuse. Remember I mentioned that quick turn-around in Sudan? Well, that particular job isn't for me anymore; it's been taken over by my cousin. He's… let's just say, not as accommodating as I am. Don't worry, I can still get your oil to South Africa.

Yours,
Sid

email_chain.subject: Deal in Cape Town - Petroleum Coke
email_chain.body:
Salam Alaikum,

Remember me? Sid, one of those sailors you knew back in Dubai. I'm in Cape Town now and I've got a good deal for you.

Three thousand metric tons of petroleum coke, 'sapphire black' grade, currently stored in an oil tanker in the Black Sea.

First offer: $500,000 (for the lot)
Second offer: $150 per metric ton for the whole load ($450,000 total).

Salam,
Sid

email_chain.subject: Re: Deal in Cape Town - Petroleum Coke
email_chain.body:
Salam,

Let me know if you're interested in the deal. The seller is firm on $150 per metric ton ($450,000 total). The deal will be finalized when you sign the contracts. An independent bank will handle the funds transfer after the transaction.

Salam,
Sid

email_chain.subject: Urgent: Petroleum Coke Offer - Cape Town
email_chain.body:
Salam,

The seller is still waiting for your response. I advised you not to delay in replying to this offer.

If you don't take it, someone else will. Who knows where this oil will end up?

Salam,
Sid

email_chain.subject: Final Offer: Petroleum Coke - Cape Town
email_chain.body:
Salam,

There's something I haven't told you. This deal seems almost too good to be true, and frankly, it might be. But, I’m in a bind. I need to make a significant amount of money quickly to start a new business. It's an opportunity I can’t pass up.

I'm not a sailor like you, but I can deliver the oil to you; I'll arrange all the details. You’ll only have to provide the funds. You'll need to deposit a sum of money into my bank account. My lawyer will prepare the contracts and deliver them to you. I’ll show you some proof that the oil is real. The...

email_chain.subject: Cargo Inquiry: Barcelona to Puerto Madryn
email_chain.body:
Hello Ms. Mendoza,

We have a cargo of 2,200 MT which we are hoping to load onto a feeder vessel around the 15th of March, departing Barcelona on the 17th. The discharge port is Puerto Madryn in Argentina.

Please confirm your earliest loading date in Barcelona and advise on the estimated transit time to Puerto Madryn.

Kind regards,
Anne Marie

email_chain.subject: Re: Cargo Inquiry: Barcelona to Puerto Madryn
email_chain.body:
Hi Anne Marie,

The cargo you have quoted will fit comfortably on the MV ACATENANGO.

This vessel will load in Aviles, Spain on the 13th of March and sail the following day to Madryn, Argentina.

Based on current schedules, arrival in Madryn and discharge would be completed by the 26th of March. This gives you an approximate two-week transit time from Spain to Madryn.

Here are some key dates:

Laycan: 13th March
Preliminary Draft/Displacement (D/D): Report of Findings by 12th March
First Week D/D Validity: 15th-22nd March
Second Week D/D Validity: 22nd-29th March
Final D/D (SPB form)
Expected Discharge: 26th March
Invoice Date: 19th March

Please confirm the delivery address is Madryn, Argentina.

Best regards,
M. Mendoza

email_chain.subject: Milestone Updates: Shipment to Puerto Madryn
email_chain.body:
Milestones to be completed between [14.03] and [20.03]

The list of milestones includes:

14.03 Milestone Tracker (MM) automatically notifies the principals of the completion of the "Report of Findings"
18.03 MM automatically notifies the vessel owner of the completion of the preliminary D/D
18.03 Vessel owner should approve the D/D within 24 hours
18.03 Vessel owner is required to download the preliminary D/D and secure the vessel
20.03 The first week of the pre-laycan D/D expires

email_chain.subject: Freight Inquiry: 3,800 MT Heavy Plates - Chittagong to Port Louis
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Ferris,

My name is Samuel. I am a vessel broker and currently representing a Chinese bulk carrier positioned in Chittagong, Bangladesh.

We have approximately 3,800 MT of heavy steel plates available for loading. The intended discharge port is Port Louis, Mauritius.

Our agents have provided a breakdown of anticipated port dues and fees in Port Louis, which they intend to deduct from the cargo. These include:

*   General Cargo Port Dues: USD 3,256.00
*   Coast Guard Charges: USD 164.00
*   Mauritius Free Airport Fee (MFAF): USD 112.80
*   Port Corporation Fees: USD 159.84
*   Generator Rental: USD 0.16/Hour * 12 Hours = USD 1.92
*   Empty Tank Cleaning: USD 10.00 * 2 Tanks = USD 20.00

Could you kindly take these anticipated deductions into account when preparing your freight quote? I can provide further documentation as required.

Thank you,
Samuel

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: 3,800 MT Heavy Plates - Chittagong to Port Louis
email_chain.body:
Dear Samuel,

Thank you for your email.

Regarding the port charges, it is generally not standard practice to pass these costs directly onto the cargo owners unless explicitly agreed upon in the terms of carriage. If you can provide documentation demonstrating that the carrier is entitled to deduct these charges from the cargo value (e.g., a relevant clause in the Bill of Lading or a prior agreement), we can consider adjusting our freight rate to compensate.

However, if these charges are solely intended to cover agency fees or other operational costs not directly related to the cargo, we cannot accommodate them within our quote.

To provide you with a more accurate freight quote, could you please provide the following information:

*   Cargo Origin
*   Steel Grade
*   Product Code (if applicable)

The more details you can provide upfront, the quicker we can process your request and minimize potential delays.

Thank you,

Alain Ferris

email_chain.body:
Dear Captain X,

Could you please provide a freight quote for 30,000 MT of soybean meal for September delivery from Chongqing to Dalian?

Regards,
Sulek

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - Soybean Meal - Chongqing to Dalian
email_chain.body:
Dear Sulek,

Our cargo agent has confirmed the rates for 30,000 MT of soybean meal from Chongqing to Dalian, as follows:

*   **Blt Chongqing:**
    *   Spot period: 10,000 USD
    *   September delivery: 9,750 USD
*   **Bunkering for Chongqing:** 80 USD
*   **F.O.B Dalian:**
    *   Spot period: 60 USD
    *   September delivery: 75 USD
*   **Bunkering for Dalian:** 30 USD

Our vessel is available for September delivery. Please let us know the shipment details when you are ready, and we'll provide a final quote.

Thanks!

Horeb Shipping
Captain X

--- Forwarded message ---
From: captain.x@horebshipping.com
Date: 2023-06-26 10:40
Subject: Additional Question

How much would the shipping cost be to the same spot, but with the destination changed to Shantou?

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - Soybean Meal - Chongqing to Dalian
email_chain.body:
Dear Captain X,

Thank you for your prompt reply.

We would like to book cargo as mentioned in your previous email (Chongqing to Dalian, September delivery).

The information you need is as follows:

*   Quantity: 30,000 MT (weight)
*   Type: Soybean meal
*   Packed in 50kg jumbo bags
*   Packed in 1,200 bags per 40'HC container
*   Destination: Dalian
*   Port of loading: Chongqing

In late June, my company and a dealer agreed on a price of 1,300 USD per MT for the soybean meal. I'm wondering if we can still proceed with the shipment at that price, given it's now September. (Referring to the overall deal, not just the freight).

Thanks in advance.

Sulek

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - Soybean Meal - Chongqing to Dalian
email_chain.body:
Dear Sulek,

I've checked with our freight representative. I'm afraid the rates we quoted in June are no longer available.

Since your July inquiry, freight costs have risen continuously. The current rate for September could be around 12,000 USD for 30,000 MT. This is considerably more expensive than the original price you were working with (1,300 USD per MT).

I'm afraid your soybean meal might have to be sold at a lower price now to accommodate the increased freight costs.

Regards,

Captain X

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - Soybean Meal - Chongqing to Dalian
email_chain.body:
Dear Captain X,

That's terrible!

It seems we won't be able to proceed.

We agreed on a contract price of only 1,300 USD per MT. Reducing the price further would result in a significant loss for us.

I'm not sure how to explain this to our client. I think it will be better to tell them to source some other cargo.

I will close this deal with the seller.

Thanks.

Sulek

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - Soybean Meal - Chongqing to Dalian
email_chain.body:
Dear Sulek,

It's a pity.

Perhaps there are ways to minimize the loss if you were to proceed with the cargo. You might be able to lock in a fixed rate for the shipment to avoid any further increases.

Best of luck with your negotiations.

Captain X

email_chain.subject: Suez Canal Delays - Shipment from China
email_chain.body:
Hi,

I've heard reports of increased transit times through the Suez Canal locks.  I have a shipment en route from China to Long Beach. Do you know if these delays are accurate, and if so, what the potential impact on my shipment might be?

Sincerely,
Donald

email_chain.subject: Suez Canal Delays Impact
email_chain.body:
Hi,

I also heard about potential delays for vessels transiting the Suez Canal. Could you provide some insight on how this might affect my shipments? I'm particularly concerned about congestion.

Sincerely,
Sarah

email_chain.subject: Re: Suez Canal Delays - Updates and Information
email_chain.body:
Dear Donald and Sarah,

Thank you for your inquiries regarding the situation at the Suez Canal. You are correct; there has been congestion and delays experienced since the Ever Given incident in March. While the canal was reopened in mid-April, a backlog of vessels accumulated, causing some continued delays.

As of May 2nd, we observed a significant number of vessels experiencing delays.

Regarding the Ever Given, the vessel was successfully refloated on March 29th. It was then held under arrest in the Canal Zone for several months before being released. 

We are actively monitoring the situation and will provide updates as they become available. To best assess the potential impact on your specific shipments, please provide your booking references or container numbers so we can check the status.

Sincerely,
The Shipping Updates Team

email_chain.subject: Inquiry: 3,400 MT Sulphuric Acid - Aqaba to Khor Fakkan
email_chain.body:
Good day Ms. Kelly,

I'm inquiring about shipping 3,400 MT of sulphuric acid from Aqaba to Khor Fakkan. Could you handle a late-July laycan, and are you open to a short load window?

Best,
J. Pye

email_chain.subject: Re: Inquiry: 3,400 MT Sulphuric Acid - Aqaba to Khor Fakkan
email_chain.body:
Hi J. Pye,

Thank you for your inquiry. Due to confidentiality protocols, I must communicate this information indirectly. Please consider this response as coming from an anonymous source within our organization.

We can likely accommodate a late July laycan. However, please understand that securing the necessary permits for this shipment may take several weeks. Given the nature of sulphuric acid and potential past restrictions, expediting the permit process will be crucial. 

We recommend engaging a third-party consultant specializing in permit acquisition for noxious substances. Their expertise can help identify the relevant issuing authorities and facilitate the application process discreetly.

A loading window of 3-4 days is feasible, but this must be specified within the permit application.

Yours,
Aqaba Shipping

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: 3000MT Garbage from New York to Venice
email_chain.body:
Ashley,

Thank you for your inquiry. I am concerned about the nature of the shipment. My organization specializes in the transportation of humanitarian aid and relief supplies. We aren't equipped for waste management. While we appreciate the request, we must decline to assist with this particular shipment.

Best regards,
James S. Michaels

-----Original Message-----
From: Ashley O'Brien <ashley.obrien@example.com>
To: James S. Michaels
Subject: Freight Inquiry: 3000MT Garbage from New York to Venice
Date: May 16, 2020

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: 3000MT Garbage from New York to Venice
email_chain.body:
Ashley,

Thank you for your inquiry. Before we can provide a quote, could you please clarify the following:

1.  What type of waste material are you shipping?
2.  Is Venice the final destination, or is it a transit point?
3.  What is the intended disposal or processing method for the waste upon arrival?

Please note, we adhere to strict environmental regulations and require full transparency regarding the nature and handling of waste shipments.

Regards,
Xee Xee

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: 3000MT Garbage from New York to Venice
email_chain.body:
Xee,

The final destination is Lomé, Togo, not Venice. We are handling all the necessary paperwork for import and disposal. The cargo is municipal solid waste, destined for a waste-to-energy plant. We need a vessel with laycan availability from May 19th to May 23rd. Can you provide a total cost estimate for shipping 3000 MT to Lomé?

Thanks,
Ashley

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: 3000MT Garbage from New York to Venice
email_chain.body:
Ashley,

We do not service Lome, Togo. Our permits only allow our ships to visit specific ports. 

Best,
James

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: 3000MT Garbage from New York to Venice
email_chain.body:
Ashley,

I am getting a bit confused. It sounds like you want to use my service to transport garbage but also sound like you are in the garbage business. My humanitarian organization is not equiped to handle toxic garbage.

Best,
James

email_chain.subject: Interesting Reads While I'm Away
email_chain.body:
Hey All,

Because I’m out of the office this week, I’m sending you some interesting industry news and updates to check out.

Here are a few highlights:

*   Click here to learn about the Fertilizer Institute’s new Code of Conduct, which includes nine guiding principles for good behavior, including the encouragement of a culture of safety and compliance with the law. "Anyone who works with anhydrous ammonia or other fertilizers must read this, and they must share it with their teams," says Brian Jennings, Director of Regulatory Affairs.
*   When a group of California manufacturers and distributors went before the California Air Resources Board (CARB) to discuss the 2013 Renewable Fuel Standard (RFS) proposed by the U.S. EPA, they did not leave empty-handed. A bill was introduced in the state legislature that would provide a tax incentive to encourage renewable fuel blending.

Best,
Brian

email_chain.body:
Hey Todd,

Just to follow up, did you ever receive a quote for your metal lath? I know you said you’d go with another vendor, but I wanted to get this completed for our records. Thanks!

From: Todd Sillington <todd.sillington@gmail.com>
To: Stewart Vanderbloemen <stewart.vanderbloemen@reznor.com>
Sent: Thursday, April 16, 2020, 12:33 PM
Subject: RE: Metal Lath Purchase

email_chain.subject: Re: RE: Metal Lath Purchase
email_chain.body:
I love that you and everyone else on the website have no idea what it takes to run a successful business. You think it’s as easy as going on constructionobserver and asking for bids. Just how much it costs for a quote and if there is a minimum number of products you have to buy.

I’d say it’s an education. Like how the Navy discovered it would lose too many crewmen if they started a major war without undergoing combat training first, so they decided to create such training so that every year they would lose fewer and fewer crews. Combat training also provided the Navy with the opportunity to evaluate newly created equipment and armaments.

In short, anyone can be an entrepreneur. You don’t need to be the richest

Paul Nogales

email_chain.subject: Vegetable Oil Shipment - Aqaba to Mombasa

Regards,
Sina

email_chain.subject: RE: Vegetable Oil Shipment - Aqaba to Mombasa
email_chain.body:
Dear Sina,

Thank you for your email. Yes, we can handle your storage in Mombasa. The price is $1.2/MT per month for a total quantity of 5,400 MT.

We can also deliver the cargo by truck directly to your factory, but the price depends on the distance.

For example:
*   Mombasa port to Machakos (70 km): $40/MT
*   Mombasa port to Athi River (50 km): $30/MT

Regards,
Basil

email_chain.subject: RE: Storage Quote Follow Up
email_chain.body:
Hi Ivan,

Regarding the vegetable oil storage and delivery quote we requested, Basil responded with the attached email.

They quoted $1.2/MT per month for storage of 5,400 MT in Mombasa.

They can also handle delivery, and their prices depend on distance. As an example, the price for Mombasa Port to Machakos (70km) is $40/MT, and to Athi River (50km) is $30/MT.

Let me know your thoughts.

Regards,
Sina

Liam

email_chain.body:
Hi Liam,

Thanks for the information. Based on the limited details, a *very* rough estimate would be around 55.00 USD/tonne (GTT) at your port. 

To provide a more accurate quote, I'd need additional information. Primarily, can you confirm the vessel is in good condition and of a suitable class as per standard tanker requirements for this type of cargo?

Regards,

Nicole

email_chain.subject: Re: Quotation Request - 15,000 DWT Vessel - Furnace Oil
email_chain.body:
Hello Nicole,

Thank you for the initial estimate. To clarify:

1) Please confirm that the intended cargo is definitely Gas Oil, and not Furnace Oil.
2) We can confirm that the cargo will be loaded on a vessel in good condition and of suitable class.

Regards,
Liam

email_chain.subject: Re: Quotation Request - 15,000 DWT Vessel - Furnace Oil
email_chain.body:
Hello Nicole,

Further to my previous email, 

1) We will *not* accept Gas Oil cargo. The cargo is Furnace Oil.
2) Yes, the vessel will be in good class and condition. We only accept high quality petroleum products.

Regards,
Liam

email_chain.subject: Re: Quotation Request - 15,000 DWT Vessel - Furnace Oil
email_chain.body:
Hi Liam,

Understood. Thank you for confirming. Please let me know the exact loading port location and preferred loading window in early April.

Nicole

[Your Name]

email_chain.subject: Follow Up: Shipment of [Cargo Name] - [Vessel Name] - [Port of Loading] to [Port of Discharge]
email_chain.body:
Hello [Shipper Name],

I wanted to follow up on our previous email regarding the shipment of [Cargo Name] from [Port of Loading] to [Port of Discharge] aboard the [Vessel Name] ([IMO #]).

The vessel is currently waiting for cargo at [Port of Loading]. We still anticipate the vessel departing [Port of Loading] on [Scheduled Departure Date].

email_chain.body:

Best regards,
[Your name]
[Your address]
email_chain.internal_note: The following section was excluded from the body because it is background information, and should not appear as part of the email chain itself: I would like to share with you a couple of situations I have recently experienced regarding sales. The main factor here is that every port of origin in this region has its own cargo’s name that differs from one port to another. Let me give you an example. Vung Tau’s oil is usually known as “XONE”, for example. If the cargo’s origin was not Vung Tau, it would be known as something different. In the first email, the seller is probably from Vung Tau, the port so he doesn’t want to use the common port of origin name, but he wants to use the name of the port where his product originates from. We have, however, to be cautious when receiving information from an agent, because often it is not completely correct. If the agent wants to sell his cargo by using an incorrect cargo name, it is much easier for him to trick the buyer by giving a name that has a higher profit for him, or a name that is more familiar for the potential buyer. This issue is something that we have to be aware of. We have to make sure that the cargo is what we think it is, and if we’re sure that we know the exact

Adam

email_chain.subject: Re: Grain Shipment Inquiry: Vancouver to Bordeaux - 50,000 MT
email_chain.body:
Dear Adam,

Thank you for your inquiry. Availability of empty vessels for departure in May 2023 is currently limited, but we anticipate some options, particularly during mid-May. To assist us in finding the best match, please advise on your preferred vessel type and any alternative vessel types you would be willing to consider.

Please be aware that due to current market conditions, some available vessels may be subject to longer demurrage periods than usual, though we understand you are familiar with our standard demurrage rates. 

Also, please let me know if you are currently considering other empty vessels besides those you have previously used.

I would also recommend you follow the Baltic Dry Index (BDI), which is currently at a nine-month high and trending upwards, potentially impacting freight rates.

For any further questions, please do not hesitate to contact our Chartering department.

Thank you.

email_chain.subject: Bridge Manning and Navigation Practices
email_chain.body:
* Why the captain and other crew leave the bridge, walk away from the wheel, and forget where the wheel is? Is this typical, or is it just human nature?

It is not typical. Any crew that is leaving the bridge for more than a few minutes will usually assign a watchkeeper and/or specify exactly where the wheel is. If the owner insists on an automatic pilot watchkeeper, it is up to the captain to comply. But that would not be my recommendation.

* If the vessel is in or near a harbor or channel where there are many vessels and navigating is a challenge, why do the ships leave the bridge and let the ship just drift out of control? Would not knowing exactly where the wheel is be a problem? I am talking about not having a person at the helm ready

Have a good day.

Alfonso

email_chain.subject: Re: Tanker Details for African Oil Lift
email_chain.body:

Alfonso, I believe I saw you message me on Facebook this morning, and the details should be there.
We had originally planned to ship from the United States, but the client has now decided to ship from Africa instead.

We hope this makes more sense now. Please let us know what else we can do to help you.

Best wishes,

Elly

email_chain.subject: African Oil Shipment Details
email_chain.body:

Please accept the following information regarding the African oil shipment. This oil is to be transported from the African port of Matadi to the South American port of San Juan de Marcona. The chartering of the vessel...

Joe Agostino - Voyage/Port Executive

email_chain.subject: RE: Inquiry: Huizhou Vessel ETA & Canned Corned Beef Booking - Reefer Booking

email_chain.subject: Voyage Inquiry: Oregon Wheat to Karachi
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Franco,

We are inquiring whether one of your vessels is capable of lifting approximately 4,700 MT of wheat from a port in Oregon to Karachi. Could you please confirm if this is feasible?

Also, could you clarify how outturn demurrage is applied in this specific case?

Looking forward to your prompt response.

Sincerely,
Paula Miller

email_chain.subject: RE: Voyage Inquiry: Oregon Wheat to Karachi
email_chain.body:
Dear Paula,

Yes, we can lift that cargo.

Kind Regards,
Gerry

email_chain.subject: RE: Voyage Inquiry: Oregon Wheat to Karachi
email_chain.body:
Dear Gerry,

To clarify, and for inclusion in our Charter Party, could you please confirm the specific time and date from which outturn demurrage would commence, assuming loading begins on Thursday, April 18th? We anticipate readiness to load (NOR tendered and accepted) on Wednesday, April 17th.

Thank you,
Paula

email_chain.subject: RE: Voyage Inquiry: Oregon Wheat to Karachi
email_chain.body:
Dear Paula,

I can confirm that outturn demurrage will commence at 1200 hours on April 17th (Wednesday). If cargo loading has not been completed by 1700 hours on April 18th (Thursday), demurrage will be assessed at a rate of US$900 per day, or pro rata.

Regards,
Gerry

email_chain.subject: RE: Voyage Inquiry: Oregon Wheat to Karachi
email_chain.body:
Dear Gerry,

Thanks.

Kind regards,
Paula

email_chain.subject: Request for Quotation: 3,000 MT Coal - Jeddah to Kaohsiung
email_chain.body:
To all Freight Forwarders,

Can you please send me a quote for shipping 3,000 MT of coal from Jeddah to Kaohsiung for shipment in early July?

Thank you!

Jason

email_chain.subject: Re: Request for Quotation: 3,000 MT Coal - Jeddah to Kaohsiung
email_chain.body:
Dear Jason,

Thank you for your email and for the opportunity to quote for this shipment of coal.

Our quotation is USD 260/MT CIF Kaohsiung.

Can you please confirm if this price is acceptable?

Kind regards,

Greg

email_chain.subject: Re: Request for Quotation: 3,000 MT Coal - Jeddah to Kaohsiung
email_chain.body:
Dear Jason,

I'm writing to update you on our previous offer. Unfortunately, our initial offer was not accepted by our client.

They are now offering an FOB Jeddah price of USD 210/MT. In addition, a demurrage charge of USD 20/MT will be added at the terminal.

Please let me know if this revised offer is acceptable to you, or if you wish to negotiate further.

Kind regards,

Greg

email_chain.subject: Re: Request for Quotation: 3,000 MT Coal - Jeddah to Kaohsiung
email_chain.body:
Dear Greg,

Thank you for the updated offer. Receiving the cargo under those conditions is acceptable to our side.

Thanks for your effort and cooperation. I look forward to receiving the details.

Regards,

Jason

email_chain.subject: Re: Request for Quotation: 3,000 MT Coal - Jeddah to Kaohsiung
email_chain.body:
Dear Greg,

Thank you for your offer. I'm afraid our client cannot accept the terms at this moment. There are some internal issues on the customer's side, and they will be receiving another cargo later this week. They won't be able to give me clear instructions before Friday.

Please stay in touch, and I will keep you updated regarding the final confirmation.

Thank you, and take care.

Jason

email_chain.subject: Re: Request for Quotation: 3,000 MT Coal - Jeddah to Kaohsiung
email_chain.body:
Dear Jason,

I'm writing to inform you of a positive response from my client. While I won’t be available during the weekend, my client can confirm your offer, but only for 2500MT, not the original 3000MT.

In that case, my FOB price remains USD 210/MT and the demurrage charge is USD 20/MT.

Please confirm this offer by the end of today.

Kind regards,

Greg

email_chain.subject: Career Exploration Assignment
email_chain.body:
Now email yourself the three emails and compare them. How are they the same? How are they different? Why does it matter?

Write a draft of a short letter you would send to an expert in the field of your career interest. The letter should explain your interest and describe your academic background and experience. Introduce an area of inquiry about the field in which you are interested, and end with a request to speak with this expert about career possibilities in the field. Draft this letter to this week’s guest speaker, Dr.

email_chain.subject: Inquiry about Computer Engineering Career Paths
email_chain.body:
Dear Dr. <NAME>,

I am writing to you because I am highly interested in computer engineering, particularly in designing advanced technology, and I'm eager to learn more about potential career paths. I'm researching work and learning opportunities available in the field.

I have researched computer engineering extensively and have taken a number of classes covering the core material. However, I'm seeking guidance on the next steps to take to become successful in this field.

I would appreciate hearing about your experiences in computer engineering and the path you took to get to where you are now. What specific classes and organizations would you recommend I consider? Any insights you could offer would be greatly valued.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

email_chain.subject: Questions Regarding a Career in Psychology
email_chain.body:
Dear Dr. <NAME>,

My name is <NAME>. I am writing to you with some questions about pursuing a career in psychology. I've heard many different perspectives on how to enter this field and am trying to determine the best approach.

I am particularly interested in learning about the necessary steps to become successful in psychology. I understand that a psychology major and fulfilling degree requirements are essential. I am also aware that internships and further specialized courses are beneficial. I was hoping you could share your personal experiences and insights into what I need to do to achieve my career goals.

Thank you for your time,

email_chain.subject: Inquiry: 7,000 MT Steel Products - Rotterdam to Long Beach
email_chain.body:
Hi Jason,

I’m looking for a vessel to ship approximately 7,000 MT of steel products from Rotterdam to Long Beach. Could you confirm if you have an available vessel and also provide your standard demurrage rate?

Thanks,
Sue

email_chain.subject: Re: Inquiry: 7,000 MT Steel Products - Rotterdam to Long Beach
email_chain.body:
Hi Sue,

I've found a vessel currently in Rotterdam, designated SB Vessel C3, but its maximum loading capacity is 5,000 MT. Would that be suitable?

If so, yes, you can proceed to confirm the vessel. Our confirmation will be valid for 48 hours. We require a week's notice before loading.

Demurrage is US$250 per container, per day, for both loading and discharging. Note that loading carries a 30% surcharge on the standard rate.

Please let me know if you would like complete charter instructions.

Regards,
Jason

email_chain.subject: Re: SB Vessel C3 - Rotterdam to Long Beach Charter
email_chain.body:
Hi Jason,

We would like to charter SB Vessel C3 from Rotterdam to Long Beach for 5,000 MT of steel products. We aim to load by June 30th.

We require 20 days of free time for discharge in Long Beach. We also need the charter party agreement to review it before we proceed.
If you have any questions, please let me know.

Regards,
John Z.

email_chain.subject: Re: SB Vessel C3 - Rotterdam to Long Beach Charter
email_chain.body:
John,

Thanks for confirming. I have prepared a draft charter party with 20 days free time for discharge. Could you please provide your insurance details for inclusion in the agreement?

Best Regards,
Jason

email_chain.subject: Re: SB Vessel C3 - Rotterdam to Long Beach Charter
email_chain.body:
John,

Thanks for the insurance details. I have finalized the charter party with the agreed-upon free time. Please confirm the details and send back a signed copy.

Best Regards,
Jason

email_chain.subject: Re: SB Vessel C3 - Rotterdam to Long Beach Charter - Signed Charter Party
email_chain.body:
Hi Jason,

Thanks for the charter party. I have signed the charter party and will send it to you via mail. Let me know if you have any questions.

Regards,
John Z.

email_chain.subject: Re: SB Vessel C3 - Signed Charter Party Attached
email_chain.body:
Hi Jason,

I have just sent you the signed charter party via mail as a PDF attachment. Please confirm receipt.

Regards,
John Z.

email_chain.subject: Re: SB Vessel C3 - Charter Confirmed
email_chain.body:
John,

Thank you. The vessel is now chartered. I will send you our bank details for payment.

Best Regards,
Jason

Cordially,

Margot Dupont

email_chain.body:

Yours sincerely,

Margot Dupont

email_chain.subject: Re: Following Up: Updated Quote, Contract, and Reference for Santos
email_chain.body:
Hi Margot,

Cordially,

Kelly Smith

email_chain.subject: Clarification: Tank Farm Reference
email_chain.body:
Hi Kelly,

The question we have is: is this the same tank farm that you've provided us with a reference for?

Cordially,

Margot Dupont

email_chain.subject: Re: Clarification: Tank Farm Reference
email_chain.body:
Hi Kelly,

Thanks for getting back to me. We've done some research, and it appears we are indeed talking about the same tank farm. We hope the reference we can provide you is suitable.

Yours sincerely,

Margot Dupont

email_chain.subject: Re: Clarification: Tank Farm Reference
email_chain.body:
Hi Margot,

I've received your email.

Hi Kelly,

We have reviewed the contract and it's acceptable. Could you please provide us with the Port of Santos rates specifically for handling crude oil for the coming 3 years?

email_chain.subject: Inquiry: Transatlantic Maize Shipment - San Juan to Port Klang
email_chain.body:

Thanks,
Gwen

email_chain.subject: Re: Inquiry: Transatlantic Maize Shipment - San Juan to Port Klang
email_chain.body:
Gwen,

Thank you for your inquiry. We would be glad to assist you with this shipment. Please see our offer below:

Commodity: MAIZE
Purchase Price (CIF Port Klang): USD 118 per MT (approximately MYR 4,410.00 per MT)

Freight Cost (FCL Basis): MYR 1.75 per 1,000 KGS (MYR 17,500.00 total for 10,000 MT)

Total (Commodity + Freight): Approximately MYR 4,427.50 per MT

Proposed Vessel: MV MING SHENG HAI (Voyage 0301), Built 2005, IMO 9301712
Vessel's Stowage Capacity: 50,000 MT
Consignment: 10,000 MT

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Best regards,
Calvin

He's heard of a 10,000-tonne load, but never 80 tonnes.

Original message from Anna Kovalchuk:

Anna Kovalchuk

[Shipping Team]

email_chain.subject: Freight Quote Request: 3500 MT Carbon Black - Thailand to China
email_chain.body:
Dear Shipping Company,

We require a freight quote for 3,500 MT of Carbon Black and Pelletized Carbon Black from TSCA Port, Thailand, to Wuhai Port, China.

email_chain.subject: Freight Quote Request: 2 Containers Carbon Black (FCC, N-330) - Thailand to China
email_chain.body:
Dear Shipping Company,

We are a trading company based in Shenzhen, China, specializing in exporting Carbon Black. We currently have 2 containers of Carbon Black (FCC, N-330) ready for loading at the TSCA Port in Thailand, originating from our manufacturer there.

We would like to request a freight quote for shipment from TSCA port, Thailand, to any of the following ports in China: Dalian, Tianjin, Qingdao, Shanghai, or Wuhan. The final destination of the Carbon Black is within China.

Please include a detailed breakdown of all associated costs in your quote, along with any other relevant information.

Sincerely,
Jane Smith

email_chain.subject: Inquiry: Purchasing and Shipping 50 MT Carbon Black from Thailand to Hong Kong
email_chain.body:
Dear Sales Team,

We are a trading company based in Hong Kong specializing in export. We are interested in purchasing 50 metric tons of Carbon Black from Thailand and having it shipped directly to Hong Kong.

To proceed with a potential purchase, we require the following information:

1. Price of Carbon Black per metric ton
2. Packing details
3. Marking details
4. Shipping cost to Hong Kong (based on order volume)
5. Port charges in Thailand and Hong Kong (based on order volume)
6. Costs for International Trade Licenses, Bank Guarantee, Bank Insurance, Warehouse storage, etc.
7. Any other miscellaneous costs involved
8. Estimated shipping time

We will make a purchase decision based on your provided prices and shipping quote.

Sincerely,
David Lee

email_chain.subject: Re: Inquiry: Purchasing and Shipping 50 MT Carbon Black from Thailand to Hong Kong
email_chain.body:
Dear Sales Team,

We are a trading company based in Hong Kong specializing in export. We are interested in purchasing 50 metric tons of Carbon Black from Thailand and having it shipped directly to Hong Kong.

To proceed with a potential purchase, we require the following information:

Sincerely,
David Lee

email_chain.subject: Re: Inquiry: Purchasing and Shipping 50 MT Carbon Black from Thailand to Hong Kong
email_chain.body:
Dear David Lee,

We are a trading company based in Thailand, specializing in exporting Carbon Black to various destinations including China and Hong Kong.

Regarding your inquiry for purchasing 50 metric tons of Carbon Black and shipping it directly to Hong Kong, we are happy to provide you with the requested information.

To proceed with a potential purchase, we require the following information:

1. Price of Carbon Black per metric ton
2. Packing details
3. Marking details
4. Shipping cost to Hong Kong (based on order volume)

Sincerely,

email_chain.subject: Freight Quote Request - 3000MT Diesel - Rotterdam to Aarhus
email_chain.body:
Good evening Mr. Menéndez,

We require a freight calculation for 3,000 MT of diesel from Rotterdam to the 13 docks at Aarhus.  Could you please confirm if your 24/7 service includes coverage for all seasonal holidays?

Kind regards,

Abbie Miller

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Request - 3000MT Diesel - Rotterdam to Aarhus
email_chain.body:
Thanks, Abbie,

Here are some details to assist with your calculations:

Please assume a loading spread of 5 to 15 days. If you use 10 days for your calculation, please note that it will be more conservative.

Here are the key terms to consider:

*   Guaranteed loading window: 5 days (We typically allow 10% extra if the barge is ready at the quay, and charge 10% per day extra from our client’s terminal if the barge is not ready).
*   Rotation time: 24 hours maximum
*   Unloading time: 24 hours maximum
*   Total transit time: 48 hours
*   All statutory holidays are considered normal workdays for shippers.
*   Routing: Oslo-Fredericia-Middelfart-Harsholm-Portland-Jakobsen

Regards,

Jose Menendez

email_chain.subject: Freight Quote: Kaohsiung - Daesan (Jet Fuel)
email_chain.body:
Mr. Regan,

Our provider, M&N, has quoted us $16.74 USD/MT to ship jet fuel from Kaohsiung to Daesan using a vessel (m/v). Do you find this price acceptable?

Thank you,
David

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote: Kaohsiung - Daesan (Jet Fuel)
email_chain.body:
David,

Please note that bunker prices for shipowners are currently higher than the general selling price of bunker fuel. This is relevant because our agent will be covering all bunker costs for VETSA trades.

Also, keep in mind that the vessel will be discharging product from Daesan to India *before* loading jet fuel in Kaohsiung for the Daesan voyage. 

Therefore, the $16.74 USD/MT is acceptable with bunker costs included, based on VETSA trade terms.

Hope this clarifies things. Let me know your thoughts.

Eddie

email_chain.subject: RE: Freight Quote: Kaohsiung - Daesan (Jet Fuel)
email_chain.body: If I understand correctly, you need to estimate the amount of bunker that will be consumed from the loading port (Kaohsiung) until the vessel arrives at the discharge port (Daesan). However, the majority of bunker consumption will occur during the voyage *from* Daesan *to* India before the vessel loads. The bunker consumed on the voyage *to* Daesan is what needs to be calculated.

email_chain.subject: Kerosene Shipment: New Orleans to Jacksonville
email_chain.body:

Could you take on 11,400 MT of kerosene from New Orleans to Jacksonville? Any insights on potential extra insurance premiums for weekend deliveries?

Thanks,
Vitoria

email_chain.subject: Re: Kerosene Shipment: New Orleans to Jacksonville
email_chain.body:
Dave,

Take a look at a surface tanker jet fuel route chart online and run the calculations. The distance is approximately 275 miles, possibly shortening to 250 miles if you cut through the shallows.

With the shallowest part being 43 feet, a 35,000 DWT tanker would need about 16' of draft. If a tanker suitable for this route existed, insurance premiums shouldn't be a major hurdle.

However, I'm not aware of any tankers currently operating that are designed for this specific shallow-water route. It's not a simple matter of 'connecting the dots'.

Insurance companies might also consider the lack of refueling points along the route, potentially leading to higher rates in case of a loss.

Bob

email_chain.body:

*   Crude Soybean Oil
*   MTOT classification
*   Customer-approved grade
*   Buyer’s own packing
*   P&S Clearing at Paranaguá
*   CIF Ravenna
*   Specifications: 80,000 BTU, 1.0% max impurities, 0.04% max moisture
*   Preferred Delivery Date: May 20 (negotiable)


Buyer's payment preference as follows:
*   35% discount on sale (25% prepaid, 10% post sight, 35% at discharge port)
*   Credit 1% x 30 days, 1% x 60 days
*   Buyer's average last offering

Please note the above supercedes my earlier request for 7,500MT. We now have requirements for 8,600 MT.

email_chain.subject: Regarding Engagement Contract Breach - Petrobras Funding
email_chain.body:
Dear Xavier,

I must express my concern regarding a potential breach of our engagement contract, specifically pertaining to our funding partnership with Petrobras. We haven't received the required proof of asset as stipulated in our agreement.

Jorge

email_chain.body:

Your service and business look good, and I've seen your name in enough magazines that I feel comfortable considering you.

What can you tell me about the process of moving from my existing brokerage firm?

Could you send me an application to get started?

Bob

email_chain.subject: Re: Potential Acquisition of Brokerage Firm
email_chain.body:
Jorge,

The amount of my compensation has not been discussed yet. Feel free to talk about it. Can you give me an idea of what kind of fee structure would be reasonable?

I hope that we can work out a mutually acceptable deal.

Thanks,
Rob

email_chain.subject: Re: Potential Acquisition of Brokerage Firm
email_chain.body:
Jorge,

I will complete the brokerage agreement draft tomorrow and will send it to you within the next three days. As you mentioned, we haven't explicitly discussed compensation, but I'm confident we can find an arrangement that works for both parties. Thanks for the fast reply.

Sent from my iPad

email_chain.subject: Local Market Expertise
email_chain.body:

Thanks,
Bob

email_chain.subject: Re: Potential Acquisition of Brokerage Firm - Numbers
email_chain.body:
Rob,

Thanks for taking a second look at the numbers. I can also re-examine them, but I still feel that they aren't as favorable as they could be.

I'm still interested in proceeding with the deal. If you're open to it, perhaps I could initially be a silent partner until things gain momentum, with the possibility of purchasing your share later.

My primary concern is ensuring mutual benefit, rather than solely focusing on increased sales figures. Could you provide some additional data so we can conduct our initial evaluation more thoroughly?

Thanks again,
George

email_chain.subject: Freight Inquiry - HFO and Gasoil
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Chen,

Could you please advise on freight rates for the following cargoes?

*   8,000 MT of HFO from Dili to Sekondi, payable against B/L (FIO)
*   7,500 MT of Gasoil from Nosy Be to Tema, payable against B/L (FIO)

Your prompt response would be greatly appreciated.

Sincerely,
George

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - HFO and Gasoil
email_chain.body:
George,

For the HFO Dili-Sekondi, I'd estimate 1 x CIF. For the Gasoil Nosy Be-Tema and assuming direct berthing at Tema, I'd estimate 2 x CIF.

Regarding the FIO terms, I'd advise against guaranteeing it. Charter party agreement might be a better approach to manage potential issues.

Have a good evening.

Larry

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - HFO and Gasoil - Example HFO fixture
email_chain.body:
George,

Geary Tankers B.V. doesn't typically handle HFO cargoes. However, for reference, here's a past example:

Malange - Pointe Noire:
1,500 tons HFO from Malange, Angola to Pointe Noire, Congo:
CIF, double nomination in Porto Amboim. Earned $34,000, time charter at $22,000.

Also, if you are looking to book HFO in Rotterdam, I have some older listings that may be of interest for comparison:

HFO Rotterdam 9/24/2012 - 7,000 tons cargo, USD 33.75/MT, delivery Rotterdam.
1,200 mt HFO, ex-shore Rotterdam, vessel at anchor, USD 34/mt, delivery Rotterdam.
HFO Rotterdam 9/20/2012 - 4,000 mt HFO.

Larry

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry - HFO and Gasoil - Geary Tankers B.V. Previous Oil Contracts
email_chain.body:
George,

To give you some further context, Geary Tankers B.V. has only had two oil contract cases in the past. One was for delivery of oil from Curacao to Pointe-a-Pitre in Guadeloupe. The other was for sale of oil from Fort-de-France in Martinique to Pointe-a-Pitre.

According to our records, the former involved the sale of 2,000 mt HFO to the M/S Mayflower Bayside owned by Epsilon Tankers Corporation, T/A Mayflower Shipping Ltd. under terms CIF (with additional provisos, and legal issues) for delivery to Port Louis in Guadeloupe, to a named buyer (Epsilon Tankers Corporation). The Master (unnamed) sailed from Rotterdam on 9/--/----, however, due to legal and other issues, this sale was never delivered. I am unsure of the exact date they sailed from Rotterdam.

Larry

email_chain.subject: Re: Thanks for your email
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Teodor,

Thank you for your email.

Regards,
Daniel

email_chain.subject: Regarding Charterer T&Cs
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Dhiraj,

I will be pleased to send you the terms and conditions on official letterhead.

While I am happy to send over T&Cs, I must caution you. I can't imagine a single lawyer who would advise giving another company this kind of access to your organization. 

If parties were doing something really shady, they would do so over the phone, in-person, or use email that deletes automatically, not just some part of the text, but the entire message thread. Asking for one bit of info could be a trick and is generally bad practice.

If you provide all the details up front, you might never get a response again.

email_chain.subject: RE: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Virginia to Turkey
email_chain.body:

Just following up on my previous email. We are still in need of shipping options from Virginia to Turkey. Do you have any suggestions for a daily service to Turkey, starting next week? This is quite urgent.

Thanks,
Susanna

email_chain.subject: RE: Iron Ore Shipment Inquiry - Virginia to Turkey
email_chain.body:
Dear Susanna,

Thank you for your inquiry. Our liner services operate from Virginia, Houston, and Long Beach, with destinations including Istanbul, İzmir, Kütahya, and Antalya in Turkey. We also offer a weekly direct service to İzmir from Savannah, with a transit time of approximately 14 days from loading in the US to discharge in Turkey. If shipping from Houston is an option, the transit time to Antalya is around 11 days. 

All these routes are served by one of our three weekly services. For a monthly schedule overview, please visit our website. Please note that we do not accept individual bookings directly. You will need to work with a freight forwarder or consolidator to place your booking.

Sincerely,
Jack

email_chain.subject: Urgent: Shipping Quote Request - Port Botany to Tokyo
email_chain.body:
Hello Owen,

Our Australian customer needs to ship powdered milk from Port Botany in Sydney to Tokyo. The initial contract is for 2,500 MT, but they may also require an additional 1,500 MT of grain.

We are aiming for a departure in the first week of July. Could you please provide a shipping quote for 4,000 MT of both commodities combined? Also, do you foresee any significant risk of port congestion at Port Botany during that period?

Many thanks,
Ivy

email_chain.subject: Re: Urgent: Shipping Quote Request - Port Botany to Tokyo
email_chain.body:
Hi Ivy,

Good morning.

The 2,500 MT powdered milk shipment should be relatively straightforward to arrange.

Regarding the additional 1,500 MT of grain, we are finding it challenging to secure a single vessel that can accommodate both cargoes simultaneously within your timeframe. While we are still in June and there are some slots available in July, the combined volume limits our options.

We could potentially fit 1,000 MT of milk powder and the 1,500 MT of grain on the same vessel. We have identified a 8,600 MT DWT M/V expected to discharge its previous cargo in July, making it available. Details below:

M/V T1
Type: General Cargo
Flag: Liberia
Call Sign: MOYO
Deadweight: 8,600 MT
Built: 1996
Hold Number: [Missing from original, cannot add]

Best regards,
Owen

email_chain.subject: Re: Urgent: Shipping Quote Request - Port Botany to Tokyo - Port Congestion Update
email_chain.body:
Hi Ivy,

Further to my previous email, concerning potential port congestion in Australia, I'm afraid the situation is worsening. Securing a berth for a shipment of this size in early July will be difficult. Railway terminals are also experiencing significant overload.

I understand this isn't ideal. Given the circumstances, this is the best option currently available. Alternatively, if you're able to postpone the shipment until October, we could likely secure a more favorable slot with greater capacity, potentially leading to a reduced per-ton price.

Let me know your thoughts.

Best regards,
Owen

email_chain.subject: Re: Urgent: Shipping Quote Request - Port Botany to Tokyo - Port Congestion Update
email_chain.body:
Dear Owen,

Thank you for the information; it's very helpful. 

Unfortunately, we need to ship the full 4,000 MT cargo in early July. We have limited storage capacity, and delaying the shipment could lead to product depreciation. Therefore, we must proceed with the original plan if at all possible.

We also anticipate additional orders for delivery in July. Could you please continue to assist us with these?

Thank you for your continued support.

Regards,
Ivy Chen

email_chain.subject: Re: Urgent: Shipping Quote Request - Port Botany to Tokyo - Port Congestion Update - Revised Options
email_chain.body:
Hi Ivy,

Owen has passed this to me as he's tied up on another project. I understand the urgency and that delaying until October is not an option. I'm looking into alternative slots, potentially in September, but these are limited and likely require breaking up the shipment.

Please find attached a quotation for both 3,000 MT and 4,000 MT shipments using a split schedule. We can ship 1,000 MT in July as originally discussed, followed by either 2,000 MT or 3,000 MT in August. We could potentially allocate 2,000 MT to a 6,000 DWT M/V scheduled to discharge in September, and 3,000 MT to a 6,500 DWT M/V also discharging in September.

To help with planning, could you please advise which cargo, milk powder or grain, you would prefer to ship in August?

Thank you.

Regards,
Martin Wong

email_chain.subject: Help with Email Response
email_chain.body:
One of my workmates asked me how to answer this email:

Email 1:
Ms. Stevens: I will be at your office tomorrow for 30 minutes. Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere. Sincerely, Nastya

Email 2:
I'm totally free tomorrow. See you tomorrow! Sincerely, Nastya

I am not sure myself. I've answered questions like these one here, but they were much more easy:

1) Say good night to Mommy!
2) Well, take your time!
3) Of course I'll help you. When and where?
4) That sounds great! I'll bring the umbrella.
5) I know. It is not important.

What is the correct way to answer to Nastya in this email?

There is a pattern for this type of 2-part email that I've observed in some specific contexts:

1. The first part is like a sign-off: "Sincerely, Nastya". 2. The second part is the
Email 3:
<My name here> looks forward to your response.
<Email 4>:
<My name here> looks forward to speaking with you further.
<Email 5>:
<My name here> looks forward to meeting with you.
<Email 6>:
<My name here> looks forward to your call.
<Email 7>:
<My name here> looks forward to learning more about your situation.


This usage appears to be common in the auto industry, with online car reviews.

Here is a blog post on this, which cites a data-driven analysis from a company called Radian6:

https://hbr.org/2013/01/the-secret-language-of-email

If we take that at face value, then one possible answer to the email in the question is:

[EMAIL 8]
Please let me know if you're free or if you want to meet elsewhere.
[EMAIL 9]
Email 4:
 We look forward to learning more about your situation.

• Did you downvote my answer? Did you downvote the answer by the user that referred to me? I'm wondering why you would do that. – Matthew Baldwin Aug 29 '17 at 18:27

email_chain.subject: Re: Help with Email Response
email_chain.body:
I think the most appropriate and professional response to the initial email from Nastya (asking if Ms. Stevens is free) is:

Ms. Stevens looks forward to meeting with you.

Or,

Ms. Stevens is looking forward to learning more about your situation.

Both of these are polite and confirm the appointment.

email_chain.body:

email_chain.body:

Vessel Name: MV WIDE BEAM 01
Type: Coal Carrier
Year Built: 2013

General Layout:

-------------------------------
--------------------------------
COAL BUNKER

------------------------
-----------------------------------
BERTH LOAD CARPET

email_chain.subject: Re: Coal Cargo Inquiry - Port Elizabeth to Venice - Vessel Details
email_chain.body:
Hi Jeremy,

Thank you for the vessel information. Just a heads-up regarding Port Elizabeth: the infrastructure is somewhat basic. Most of the coal is stored at berths that are either elevated or located away from the water, requiring side-loading. These berths are essentially ash ponds filled from barges, stockpiles, or rail. The coal needs to be transported to the vessel. The actual loading process will depend on the specific coal berth.

The average loading rate is usually between 600-800 MT/hour. However, given the absence of draft restrictions and berthing limitations, we anticipate an average loading rate of around 1500 MT/hour. We might even reach 2,000 MT/hour if the coal can be delivered to the berth efficiently.

Also, be advised that water levels in the port tend to be low in March.

Regards,
Brian

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Gdańsk to Tanger
email_chain.body:

S. M. F.

email_chain.subject: Crane Capacity Inquiry
email_chain.body:
Dear Ms. Bennett,

I hope this email finds you well.

Our company is evaluating stevedoring options for upcoming shipments. While we recognize Bicheno Terminals provides cranes and loading equipment, we typically handle the discharge with our own personnel to ensure efficiency and quality control. We pride ourselves on fast berthing and cargo operations, which is crucial for maintaining berthing rights and a successful shipment.

Could you please provide information regarding your crane capacity at your ports? Also, can you give me an estimate of service time for ships carrying 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ of cargo?

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,
Edward

email_chain.subject: Re: Crane Capacity Inquiry - Length and Capacity
email_chain.body:
Dear Ms. Bennett,

Thank you for your reply. 

It appears that neither your terminal nor mine possesses cranes strong enough to handle vessels with those specifications. However, we seem to share a common interest with the island of Grande Comore in identifying a reputable port known for quality equipment and fast service, particularly for sensitive cargo requiring meticulous handling.

As you know, many shipping companies prefer using their own personnel to discharge cargo due to the specialized attention their vessels need. One challenge is finding stevedoring companies equipped to handle large vessels efficiently. This is where I believe your expertise could be invaluable.

Would you be interested in exploring a potential collaboration with us on this project?

Sincerely,
Edward

email_chain.subject: Re: Crane Capacity Inquiry - Length and Capacity
email_chain.body:
Hi Edward,

Have you considered using a multi-purpose dock such as Port Natal?

They have the most advanced docking equipment and very experienced crews.

They are also known for their speed, with a reported average unloading time of 15 minutes per ship. 

Another option would be to engage a third-party stevedoring company.

I know a company called "Aloha Stevedoring" who are capable of handling your requirements. They're known for their expertise, ships, and docks.

All the best,
Cory

email_chain.subject: Re: [Port of Bicheno] Third-party option
email_chain.body:
Hi Cory,

I was discussing this matter with a friend who lives near our terminal.

They have recently opened a new terminal that can handle vessels with 2,600 meters and 6,500m³ cargo capacity.

They are looking to expand their business and seeking quality collaborators.

I think they would be interested in handling this work for you.

The only issue is that their terminal is located in the Philippines.

If you'd like to speak with them directly, please let me know.

Best regards,
Edward

email_chain.subject: Re: [Port of Bicheno] New Terminal in the Philippines
email_chain.body:
Hi Edward,

Cory here.

I happen to be in the Philippines.

I'm pleased to learn about the new terminal; I can help you here.

My company can offer you the best rates and top-notch service for your cargo.

What are your target loading rates?

We are eager to discuss this further and await your reply.

Cory

email_chain.subject: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda
email_chain.body:
Dear Sir/Madam,

We require a vessel with a total capacity for 36,000 metric tonnes of glycol to be shipped from Mexico to Luanda, Angola.

Please advise if you have any suitable vessels available.

Best regards,
Your Name

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda
email_chain.body:
Dear Your Name,

Regarding your inquiry for a vessel to transport 36,000 metric tonnes of glycol from Mexico to Luanda, Angola, I have a vessel that might be suitable.

While 36,000 MT translates to approximately 3,600 m3 (assuming a density of 1 ton/m3), the vessel has a capacity of 5,500 m3 (equivalent to 5,500,000 litres).

The shipment cost would be US$100,000. 

Please let me know if this is acceptable.

Best regards,
Shipping Broker

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda
email_chain.body:
Dear Shipping Broker,

Thank you for the quick response. I need to clarify: the price of the glycol is $10/litre. Therefore, the shippers have stated that the value of the space on the vessel, 5,500 m3 (5,500,000 litres) will be US$55,000,000 (not $55,000, as you mentioned). The net profit for the shippers is therefore US$55,000,000 - US$100,000 = US$54,900,000.

How does this change the arrangements and your potential commission?

Best regards,
Your Name

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda - Commission Proposal
email_chain.body:
Dear Your Name,

Thank you for the clarification regarding the shippers' profit. Assuming this offer is accepted, my commission structure as the agent would be as follows:

100% of the net profit is $54,900,000
Commission is 5% of net profit is $2,745,000
The balance of $52,155,000 is to be deposited by you in my bank account (as a deposit for the space on the vessel for the glycol), and you will then get the original balance of $100,000 less commission.

Please find attached a draft contract for your review and signature. I will provide a signed copy for your records once you return a signed version. 

If you have any queries, please do not hesitate to contact me.

Best regards,
Shipping Broker

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda - Contract Signed
email_chain.body:
Dear Shipping Broker,

Thank you. The contract has been signed and returned.

To facilitate the payment process, would you please provide the bank details for the bank which the shippers have an account with? I will then deposit the balance of $52,155,000 and receive the commission of $2,745,000.

Best regards,
Your Name

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda - Bank Details Provided
email_chain.body:
Dear Your Name,

Thank you. The bank details have been provided in the attached document.

Please confirm the deposit is completed.

Best regards,
Shipping Broker

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda - Deposit Confirmation
email_chain.body:
Dear Shipping Broker,

The balance, US$52,155,000 is now in the bank account.  Please let me know if you have any queries.

Best regards,
Your Name

email_chain.subject: Re: Glycol Shipment Inquiry - Mexico to Luanda - Payment Instructions
email_chain.body:
Dear Your Name,

Many thanks for your cooperation. The bank details of the shippers have been provided to you in a separate email and are also attached here. Please arrange for the payment to be made to the shippers.

Please advise when the payment has been processed.

Best regards,
Shipping Broker

email_chain.subject: Freight Quote Confirmation - Damieta to Mersin
email_chain.body:

Thank you for your prompt reply. We are now expecting the vessel to be ready for loading around May 7th. As per your quotation, we would require a rate of $95/MT to transport the cargo from Damieta to Mersin.

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Confirmation - Damieta to Mersin
email_chain.body:
Dear Jon,

Thank you for your email. 

Regarding the Bill of Lading, please note that it should be clearly indicated as a multi-user Bill of Lading. Please ensure the following details are accurately reflected:

A. Fuel specification: Full clean fuel to EN590 specification.
B. Quantity of cargo.
C. Port of Loading: Damieta.
D. Port of Discharge: Mersin.
E. Latest Estimated Time of Arrival (ETA) of the vessel.
F. Final agreed quantity of cargo.
G. Final date of loading.
H. Terms of Payment.

Please send us a copy of the Bill of Lading including the terms of payment and the actual loading date.

As per our agreement, payment will be processed upon receipt of the officially signed Bill of Lading.

Regards,

Jane Jenkins

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Quote Confirmation - Damieta to Mersin

Regards,

Jane Jenkins

email_chain.subject: Freight Inquiry: Sumatra to Suez - 20,000 MT Iron Ore
email_chain.body:
Hey Jake,

Let’s say we’re looking to ship 20,000 MT of iron ore from Sumatra to Suez around August. How about a four-week laycan, starting August 1st?

Any initial thoughts on freight rates and estimated voyage duration?

Regards,
Stanley

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Sumatra to Suez - 20,000 MT Iron Ore
email_chain.body:
Dear Mr. Steffes,

Hamburg South America Line was approached by your agents, E & T Group, regarding the potential transport of iron ore from Indonesia to South America. We understand you are looking for offers for the transport of approximately 20,000 MT of iron ore with a laycan from August 1st to the beginning of September.

The main characteristics are as follows:

- Loading location: Sumatra region
- Cargo: Iron ore (Fe 62%)
- Discharge port: To be selected and confirmed by the buyer (originally Suez, but confirm this)

Please send your offers on a non-negotiable basis (ex works) in USD based on the FOB Hamburg price of iron ore (currently US$78/MT, for reference).

For the selected shipping line, please provide freight and sailing costs in USD (ex works).

In addition to the above...

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Sumatra to Suez - 20,000 MT Iron Ore
email_chain.body:
Hi Stanley,

Sorry for the delay in getting back to you. We've been dealing with an issue regarding the vessel's bills of lading.

I understand your cargo will be subject to an inspection at the port of discharge. Since this is outside of our direct control, please contact your broker or agent to determine the specific inspection requirements, including duration and optimal timing.

The original bill of lading, which was issued in your absence, contained a statement suggesting we were responsible for the inspection's duration. This paragraph has subsequently been removed.

We understand that your client will be taking full responsibility for their merchandise at the port of discharge and therefore they should assume responsibility for ensuring customs clearance. We understand that you are working with our agent at the port of discharge to file the necessary documents. However, if you encounter any problems, please feel...

email_chain.subject: Re: Freight Inquiry: Sumatra to Suez - 20,000 MT Iron Ore
email_chain.body:
Hi Jake,

I hope you’re well.

The client has changed the discharge port from Suez to Antwerp, Belgium. Unfortunately, we had to sign a bill of lading without notifying you beforehand because the cargo was already on board and sailing. We will now follow your advice and contact our agent at the port of discharge to ensure that all necessary documents are filed to clear the cargo through customs.

As requested, I will also forward a copy of the bill of lading to you and will let you know as soon as we have a confirmed inspection schedule for the cargo.

Regards,
Stanley

email_chain.subject: Update: Antwerp Cargo Clearance and Inspection
email_chain.body:
Hi Jake,

We have received confirmation from our agent in Antwerp that the necessary documents have been filed and the cargo has cleared customs.

The inspection is scheduled to start tomorrow morning at 9:00 AM.

I will forward a copy of the bill of lading to you as soon as possible.

Regards,
Stanley

email_chain.subject: Container Ship Inquiry
email_chain.body:
Hello Sir,

I was wondering about your opinion on container ship construction in China. Do you foresee a significant increase in large container ship production there?

Also, I'm curious about your perspective on investment strategies: is it generally more advantageous to own a smaller container ship outright, or to hold a partial interest in a larger vessel?

Thank you,
Andre

email_chain.subject: Follow up: Container Ship Investment Strategy
email_chain.body:
Dear Sir,

Following up on my previous email, I've been doing some research into the container ship business. I'm formulating some ideas about optimal investment.

Specifically, I'm still considering the question of whether it's better to own a small container ship outright versus a share in a larger vessel. I believe the container shipping industry's prospects are generally positive, especially with the current strength of the market.

My initial conclusion, based on my limited understanding, is that owning a smaller container ship might be preferable. However, I'd greatly value your input.

Thank you,
Andre

email_chain.subject: Container Ship Investment - Further Thoughts
email_chain.body:
Dear Sir,

Further to my previous communications, I've continued studying the container business and refining my understanding. After considerable thought, I've arrived at what seems like a logical approach.

My current conviction is that owning a smaller container ship offers greater stability in the long term compared to owning a stake in a larger vessel. 

I would greatly appreciate your feedback on this evolving perspective. I look forward to hearing from you.

Thank you,
Andre
